chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: In this problem, we will calculate the profitability index for investment.

**The profitability index** is a method that is used to find out if an investment is acceptable or not. It is determined as a fraction of the sum of the present values of all expected future cash flows from an investment and invested amount of money.

Let's explain the profitability index definition now. Basically, the profitability index compares the amount of money that we invest with the amount that we get from the investment. For example, if we buy the machine, its cost will represent invested amount. On the other hand, we will use the machine, produce products, sell them and get cash flows for a certain number of years.

Due to the **time value of money**, we can not compare cash flows from different periods. Thus, we have to determine the present value of all cash flows that we expect to receive, and then we can sum them up. Once we calculate the sum of all present values, we can compare it with the invested amount (by dividing them).

Now, **if the fraction of the sum of all present values of cash flows and the invested amount is above 1, the investment should be accepted**, as it adds value to the company. Otherwise, investment should be rejected.

Next, we can depict the profitability index (PI) with the formula:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{PI}&=\frac{\text{PV}}{\text{I}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

Also, we can depict the formula for calculation of present value of expected future cash flows (PV):

$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}&=\dfrac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\dfrac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+...+\dfrac{\text{CF}_\text{t}}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^\text{t}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$\text{CF}_\text{i}$ = Expected Future Cash Flows from Investment\
R = Discount Rate\
t = Number of Time Periods (Years)\
I = Investment Cost (Invested Amount)

Let's identify the given variables:


|Variable |$\hspace{15pt}$Value| 
|--|--| 
| Investment Cost|$\hspace{10pt}$-$16,700 | 
|Cash Flow form Year 1|$\hspace{15pt}$\$9,700| 
|Cash Flow form Year 2 | $\hspace{15pt}$$7,800| 
|Cash Flow form Year 3 | $\hspace{13pt}$                                  $4,300 | 
|Discount Rates|10%, 15%, 22%|

**a) The profitability index for the discount rate of 10 percent**

Now, we can calculate the present value of expected future cash flows for the discount rate of 10 percent.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}&=\dfrac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\dfrac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+\dfrac{\text{CF}_\text{3}}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^\text{3}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{9,700}{\left(1+0.10\right)^1}+\dfrac{7,800}{\left(1+0.10\right)^2}+\dfrac{4,300}{\left(1+0.10\right)^\text{3}}\\[15pt]
&=8,818.8+6,446.28+3,230.65\\[15pt]

&=\boxed{\bf\$18,495.73}
\end{aligned}$$

**The present value of expected future cash flows is $18,495.73.**

Now, we can calculate profitability index for the discount rate of 10 percent.
$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}
&=\frac{\text{PV}}{\text{I}}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{18,495.73}{16,700}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf1.11}
\end{aligned}$$

**The profitability index of investment is 1.11 at a discount rate of 10 percent. We should invest in such a project since the profitability index is above 1.**

**b) The profitability index for the discount rate of 15 percent**

Next, we can calculate the present value of expected future cash flows for the discount rate of 15 percent.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}&=\dfrac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\dfrac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+\dfrac{\text{CF}_\text{3}}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^\text{3}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{9,700}{\left(1+0.15\right)^1}+\dfrac{7,800}{\left(1+0.15\right)^2}+\dfrac{4,300}{\left(1+0.15\right)^\text{3}}\\[15pt]
&=8,434.78+5,897.92+2,827.32\\[15pt]

&=\boxed{\bf\$17,160.02}
\end{aligned}$$

**The present value of expected future cash flows is $17,160.02.**

Now, we can calculate profitability index for the discount rate of 15 percent.
$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}
&=\frac{\text{PV}}{\text{I}}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{17,160.02}{16,700}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf1.03}
\end{aligned}$$

**The profitability index of investment is 1.03 at a discount rate of 15 percent. We should invest in such a project since the profitability index is above 1.**

**c) The profitability index for the discount rate of 22 percent**

Now, we can calculate the present value of expected future cash flows for the discount rate of 22 percent.

$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}&=\dfrac{\text{CF}_1}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^1}+\dfrac{\text{CF}_2}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^2}+\dfrac{\text{CF}_\text{3}}{\left(1+\text{R}\right)^\text{3}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{9,700}{\left(1+0.22\right)^1}+\dfrac{7,800}{\left(1+0.22\right)^2}+\dfrac{4,300}{\left(1+0.22\right)^\text{3}}\\[15pt]
&=7,950.82+5,240.53+2,368.04\\[15pt]

&=\boxed{\bf\$15,559.38}
\end{aligned}$$

**The present value of expected future cash flows is $15,559.38.**

Next, we can calculate profitability index for the discount rate of 22 percent.
$$\begin{aligned} \text{PV}
&=\frac{\text{PV}}{\text{I}}\\[15pt]
&=\frac{15,559.38}{16,700}\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\bf0.93}
\end{aligned}$$

**The profitability index of investment is 0.93 at a discount rate of 22 percent. We should reject such a project because the profitability index is below 1.**

**To conclude, the profitability index of an investment with the discount rate of:**
- **10 percent is 1.11**
- **15 percent is 1.03** 
- **22 percent is 0.93**.
